citation.article-title: Polaribacter gen. nov., with three new species, P. irgensii sp. nov., P. franzmannii sp. nov. and P. filamentus sp. nov., gas vacuolate polar marine bacteria of the Cytophaga-Flavobacterium-Bacteroides group and reclassification of 'Flectobacillus glomeratus' as Polaribacter glomeratus comb. nov.

p.s: Polaribacter (Po.lar.i.bac'ter. Polaro M.L. adj. polaris pertaining to the geographic poles; bacter from the Gr. n. baktron for rod or staff; Polaribacter rod-shaped bacterium from a polar region)
Psychrophilic or psychrotrophic Gram-negative nonmotile rods.
Cell size varies between 2 and 48 μm in length and 0.25-1.6 μm in diameter depending on growth medium, temperature, and age of the culture.
Coccoid bodies are often seen in ageing cultures.
Cells produce orange-, salmon- or pink-coloured pigments which are not flexirubins.
Gas vesicles are produced in some strains.
Some strains may be flagellated, but motility has never been observed in wet mounts.
Cells grow well in media which contain NaCl.
Cells produce acid from a number of carbohydrates.
Starch is hydrolysed by these bacteria.
Cells can grow on yeast extract and Casamino acids.
G + C content range is 31-33 mol%.

All strains have been isolated from polar marine environments and grow well at low temperatures. 16s rRNA sequence analysis clearly indicates that this genus of bacteria forms a distinct clade of the Cytophaga-Flavobacterium-Bacteroides phylum. Polaribacter filamentus is the type species of the genus.
